note.p: “proud venus there / Glittering in the evening air” (MS III)—A favorite adjective of Ruskinʼs, glittering is found applied several times to stars and constellations in one of his sources for information about astronomy, Sandford and Merton, as in “glorious, glittering bodies . . . now above us” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 165). However, Ruskinʼs other epithet for Venus, proud, is not typical. In poetry, Venus is more commonly admired for its beauty than for its pride. In volume 2, “On Astronomy”, of Scientific Dialogues by Jeremiah Joyce, the Tutor begins the conversation, “Of Venus”, by glossing “the most beautiful” of planets with Miltonʼs hymn to the Creatorʼs “glorious works” in Paradise Lost:

lg.l: Fairest of Stars, last in the train of Night
If better thou belong not to the dawn,
Sure pledge of day, that crownʼst the smiling Morn
With thy bright Circlet, praise him in thy Sphere
While day arises, that sweet hour of Prime.

div.p: (bk. 5, lines 166–70, in Milton, Complete Poems and Major Prose, ed. Hughes, 306)

note.p: Ruskin does draw on Miltonʼs hymn to frame his earlier poem, “The Sun”, but his sources for the astronomical knowledge in “The Constellations” remain to be identified.

In Joyceʼs “Of Venus”, the Tutor goes on to explain how Venus appears as the “Evening Star” when positioned east of the sun, and as the “Morning Star” when west of the sun—appearances resulting from the planetʼs orbit as viewed from the Earth. To illustrate these more scientific astronomical observations, here and elsewhere the Tutor quotes lines from The Excursion (1728) by David Mallet (1701/2–65) (bk. 2, lines 77–81, quoted in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, conversation 19, 2:198, 202).

“belt of orion” (MS III)—Orion (the Hunter). According to Ruskinʼs geography text, “Orion, containing his Sword and luminous Belt”, is considered one of the “most remarkable” constellations “to the naked eye or telescope”, along with “Taurus, containing the Pleiades; and Ursa Major, containing the Pointers to the North Star: all visible in our winter evenings” (Goldsmith, Grammar of General Geography, 8). Situated south of Taurus (the Bull) and Gemini (the Twins, Castor and Pollux), which are constellations in the zodiac, Orion is viewed along the celestial equator, below the ecliptic. In the northern hemisphere, it rises low on the eastern horizon during winter evenings and transits westward.

Among the most ancient named constellations, Orion is mentioned, for example, in Homerʼs Odyssey as one of the constellations that guide Odysseus (bk. 5), and he also appears to Odysseus among the dead in the underworld (bk. 11). In mythology, Orion is a great hunter; in the sky, he wields a mighty club in one hand and a lion skin as a shield in the other. His belt, the most noticeable visible feature of the constellation, is formed by three equidistant stars in a straight row. In one version of his story, as recounted in an American illustrated book about the constellations published in 1824: “Orion was a man of gigantic stature and greatly celebrated as a hunter. In the island of Crete he accompanied Diana and Latona to the chase, and there died by the bite of a scorpion which the earth produced under his feet, to punish his vanity in boasting that there did not exist an animal which he could not conquer. At the request of Diana, he was placed among the stars, in a situation directly opposite to that of the Scorpion” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 69; for other tales about the death of Orion, see Ridpath, Star Tales, 135).

div.note: p>“red mars . . . / On his throne” (MS III)—The “dusky red appearance” of the planet Mars is commonly remarked (coversation 20, “Of Mars”, in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 2:207). The iconography of seating the Olympian gods on thrones may have been most familiar to Ruskin from the synod of the gods in book 15 of Homerʼs Iliad (in Popeʼs translation), after Jupiter has rebuked Juno for assisting the Trojans. Juno provokes Mars to resentful rage for the loss of his son, Ascalaphus. Minerva “[s]tarts from her azure throne to calm the god”, reminding him of the futility of striving against Jove, and “[t]his menace fixʼd the warrior to his throne; / Sullen he sat, and curbʼd the rising groan” (bk. 15, lines 141, 160–61). This passage also pertains to the association of Mars and Venus, Juno having conspired with Venus in book 14 to distract Jupiter from the battlefield with love‐making and sleep (Homer, Iliad, trans. Pope, 307, and see 303–7, 292–97). For Ruskinʼs 1824 edition of Popeʼs Iliad, see Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth: Physical Descriptions. For the possibility that the poemʼs configuration of Venus, Mars, and Orion could have been based on real‐life observation, see the “The Constellations” apparatus: Discussion—Real‐life Observations.

note.p: “the greater bear is seen / Then charlesʼs wain with his bright team” (MS III)—Turning back from a planet to the constellations, Ruskin begins with the largest circumpolar constellation, Ursa Major (the Great Bear), which contains the oblong configuration of four stars also known as the Plough or Charlesʼs Wain, with another three stars forming its “team” of horses. In both Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton and Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the pupils are shown stars in the Plough or Wain that serve as “pointers” to the North Star, enabling the boys to determine compass bearings in the dark. As Joyceʼs Tutor explains, “if you wish to be a young astronomer”, a youth “must learn to find these [cardinal compass] points without the assistance of the sun”; and he directs their eyes to “those seven stars which are in the constellation of the Great Bear” (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, “Of Astronomy”, conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 2:15–16).

Considered as part of the larger constellation, the seven stars “form a quadrilateral figure in the back of the Bear; the other three stars project from one of the angles in a curved line, and constitute the tail”; however, the seven stars “occupy but a small part of the whole constellation, which is one of the most extensive in the heavens” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 23). Among the oldest named constellations in classical sources familiar to Ruskin, the Great Bear is mentioned along Orion by Homer in the Odyssey (bk. 5), and as ever‐present in the sky, never bathing in the sea. The best‐known story in western classical poetry about the Great Bear is told by Ovid in Metamorphoses. The nymph Callisto, a companion of the huntress, Artemis [Diana], is raped by Zeus [Jupiter]. Unable to conceal her pregnancy, Callisto is shunned by Artemisʼs chaste band, and she becomes prey to the revenge of Hera [Juno]. She is saved by metamorphosis into a bear, only to be hunted by Artemis as well as by Callistoʼs own unwitting son by Zeus, Arcas. Zeus rescues Callisto from this predicament by setting her in heaven as a constellation (Ridpath, Star Tales, 172–74, and see 174–75 for other stories; see also Ursa Minor, below).

“the dragon“ (MS III)—Also a circumpolar constellation, Draco (the Dragon) winds around the North Star (Polaris) between Ursa Major (the Great Bear) and Cepheus. It is among the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

In mythology, “[b]y some writers the Dragon is represented as the monster which protected the golden apples in the garden of Hesperides, and which was slain by Hercules [Heracles]. Juno [Hera], who presented these apples to Jupiter [Zeus] on their nuptials, took Draco up into heaven, and made of it this constellation, as a reward for its faithful services. It has since become an emblem of vigilance. Others maintain, that in a war with the Giants, this Dragon was brought into the combat, and opposed to Minerva [Athena], who threw it round the axis of the earth before it had time to uncoil, where it remains to this day” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 23). Hercules, who slew the dragon as one of his labors, has his own constellation nearby. Ridpath draws on Hesiod and the Bibliotheca of Apollodorus for versions of the story (Star Tales, 92).

“berenices golden hair“ (MS III)—Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair) is situated between Ursa Major and Boötes and south of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs)—or, as Green specifies, referring to a star in Canes Venatici, “[a] little to the south of Cor Caroli [Charlesʼs Heart]” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 52). Eratosthanes and Ptolemy represented the asterism as the hair of famous women, but counted its stars among the constellation Leo (the Lion), and it was not treated as a separate constellation until the sixteenth century (Ridpath, Star Tales, 78).

Green describes “[t]his remarkable cluster of minute stars” as “shine[ing] with a light somewhat like that of the Milky Way”; and he goes on to relay the story as told by the Latin writer, Hyginus, about a historical, third‐century B.C. Egyptian woman, Berenice. She was “married her own brother, Evergestes, one of the kings of Egypt, whom she loved with much tenderness. Upon an important occasion, having left her to engage in a dangerous enterprise, she vowed to dedicate to Venus [Aphrodite] her hair, which was extremely beautiful, if he should be restored to her in safety. Some time after his victorious return, the locks which had been deposited in the temple of Venus, according to her oath, disappeared. The king expressing great regret for their loss, Connon, his astronomer, publicly reported that Jupiter [Zeus] had taken them away and placed them among the stars. Being sent for by Evergestes, Connon pointed out this constellation, saying, ‘There, behold the locks of the queen’. As this group was not before on the maps, being among the unformed stars until that time, this satisfied the king of the truth of Connonʼs declaration” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 52). Ridpath clarifies that the historical Berenice of Egypt married her cousin, Ptolemy III, not her brother (Star Tales, 79).

“the northern crown“ (MS III)—Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown) appears between Boötes and Hercules. It was included in Ptolemyʼs list of forty‐eight constellations, and “may very easily be known by the circular form of its principal stars, which are six in number. A crown or garland may readily be imagined from the striking arrangement of the whole group” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 49).

The mythology, according to Green, commemorates “a crown presented by Bacchus [Dionysius] to Ariadne, the daughter of Minos, second king of Crete. Theseus, king of Athens, was shut up in the celebrated labyrinth of Crete, erected by Daedalus, to be devoured by Minotaur; but he slew the monster, and being furnished with a clew by Ariadne, who was passionately attached to him, made his escape from the intricate windings of his place of confinement. He afterwards married Ariadne, but soon treated her in the most cruel manner, so that she was induced, according to some writers, to commit suicide. After her death the crown of stars given by Bacchus was made this constellation” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 49). Theseusʼs mistreatment consisted in abandoning her on the island of Naxos. According to other versions of the story, Bacchus rescues and marries her (Ridpath, Star Tales, 82).

“the very fiery swan“ (MS III)—Cygnus (the Swan), or Northern Cross, lies south of Draco, between Cepheus and Hercules. It was included in the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy. The constellation “may very easily be recognised”, Green says, “as its principal stars form a large and regular cross in the Milky Way, from which circumstance the whole group is often called the Cross”. Perhaps because the stars forming Cygnus occur within an area of the Milky Way that Green describes as “remarkably brilliant”, Ruskin calls the Swan “fiery” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 43).

The constellationʼs mythology is surrounded by “considerable doubt”, Green says. “According to the Poets, Orpheus, the celebrated musician of antiquity, having been murdered by the cruel priestess of Bacchus, was after his death changed into this swan and placed near his harp” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 44). Green does not mention the myths identifying the swan as Zeusʼs disguise for committing rape, in some stories pursuing the nymph Nemesis, in others the queen of Sparta, Leda (Ridpath, Star Tales, 86–87).

“starry charlesʼs heart“ (MS III)—Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) is a star in the constellation Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs). The constellation, which lies between Boötes and Ursa Major, was introduced by the Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius in 1687 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 59).

Prior to the invention of the constellation, its prominent star was named Cor Caroli Regis Martyris “in honour of Charles I” by “Sir Charles Scarborough [1615–94], physician to Charles II” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 31). A legend held that the star blazed brightly on the day in May 1660 when Charles II rode into London to restore the Stuart monarchy. Early in the nineteenth century, a German astronomer, Johann Bode (1747–1826), misattributed the naming of the star to the English astronomer, Edmond Halley (1656–1742), and moved its invention forward into the eighteenth century; independently, another error identified the starʼs namesake as Charles II. The starʼs proper origin, however, lies in the seventeenth century with those who regarded Charles I as a martyr (Warner, letter to the editor; Ridpath, Star Tales, 60). See also Charlesʼs Oak, below, which Halley did name after Charles II.

“the telescope” (MS III)—Telescopium Herschelii (Herschellʼs telescope) is now an obsolete constellation, but Green acknowledged it in Astronomical Recreations, published in 1824. The constellation was created in 1789 by the Hungarian astronomer, Maximilian Hell (1720–92), who devised it from “a few of the stars of Auriga [the Charioteer]. . . . It is intended to perpetuate the name of Herschell [William Herschel, 1738–1822] and the form of the instrument by which he discovered the planet Uranus in the year 1781” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 33). Ridpath explains that Hell originally created two constellations commemorating Herschel telescopes, which were reduced to one by Johann Bode in 1801 (Star Tales, 205–6).

“the little horse“ (MS III)—Equuleus (Little Horse), is positioned south of Cygnus (the Swan) and Delphinus (the Dolphin), and next to its vastly larger and more famous relative, Pegasus. Equuleus was included in Ptolemyʼs list of forty‐eight constellations.

This very small constellation represents only the head of a horse named, “according to the Poets, . . . Celeris, given by Mercury to Castor, who was celebrated for his skill in the management of this noble animal” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 59).

“the stupid goose“ (MS III)—Ruskin lists Anser (the Goose) singly, separated from its predator in the paired constellation, Vulpecula et Anser (Fox and Goose); see Vulpecula, below. Vulpecula et Anser “crosses the Milky Way a littie to the south of Cygnus, and to the north of the Arrow [Sagitta]” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 48).

Vulcepula et Anser was introduced by the Polish astronomer, Johannes Hevelius (1611–87), who depicted it as a fox with a goose captured in its jaws. The haplessness of the bird may account for Ruskinʼs epithet of “stupid”, but by dividing the constellation in two Ruskin also avoids drawing attention to the gooseʼs fate. A precedent for separating the fox from the goose extends back to Hevelius himself, who named the constellation both as a single entity, Vulpecula cumAnser, and as two distinct entities, which were afterward sometimes reunited as Vulpecula et Anser. Nowadays, the goose is omitted altogether, leaving only Vulpecula (Ridpath, Star Tales, 182–83).

Perhaps a predatory and carnivorous fox offended nineteenth‐century sensibility, since Green omits any mention of what is happening to the goose, Ruskin not only separates the constellations, but also places Lepus (the Hare) between them. If he intended to shield the goose from the fox, he undercut the effort by giving the hare the epithet “timid”.

“the very timid hare“ (MS III)—Lepus (the Hare) is south of Orion, just below the celestial equator, and therefore counts among “some of the southern” constellations declared in Ruskinʼs title of his poem. Lepus is one of the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

“The Hare seems to have been placed at the feet of Orion in compliment to his skill in the chase” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 98). Ridpath adds that some mythographers viewed the nearby dog constellations, Canis Major and Canis Minor, as helping in Orionʼs chase of the hare. The stories that Ridpath summarizes about the hare suggest that it was read less with mythological associations than with moral and animal tales (Star Tales, 115–16). .

“the lesser bear“ (MS III)—Ursa Minor (the Lesser Bear) is a circumpolar constellation containing Polaris (the Pole Star) itself, which forms the tip of his tail. It was one of the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

“Ursa Minor, according to ancient Greek tradition, became a constellation in memory of Arcas, the son of Callisto and grandson of the cruel Lycaon, king of Arcadia. The current opinion is, that Arcas was changed by Jupiter [Zeus] into a bear, and placed here in the heavens; but it is thought by others, with more probability we think, that this was done by Juno [Hera] (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 21–22; see also Ursa Major, above). According to another myth, Ursa Minor is one of the nymphs who nursed the infant Zeus (Ridpath, Star Tales, 177).
“the cunning fox“ (MS III)—For the invention and location of Vulpecula (the Fox), see Anser (the Goose), above.

“the blessed cross“ (MS III)—Crux (the Cross or Southern Cross) is a southern constellation, made up of “four fine stars near the hind feet of the Centaur [Centaurus], . . . which are among the most brilliant in southern latitudes” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 102). The stars were known to Ptolemy, but he considered them as part of Centaurus in his catalogue of forty‐eight constellations. As Ridpath explains, although visible to the ancient Mediterranean world, the stars were lost to view in the north owing to precession in the Earthʼs rotational axis. The stars were rediscovered and charted by European explorers sailing south in the sixteenth century, and it came to be used by navigators since its axis points to the southern pole (Ridpath, Star Tales, 84–85). The Southern Cross would never have been visible to Ruskin.

“great charlesʼs oak“ (MS III)—Rober Carolinum (Charlesʼs Oak) was also a southern constellation, which would never have been visible to Ruskin. The constellation is now obsolete. According to Ridpath, its obsolescence was caused by the star survey undertaken from the Cape of Good Hope by the French astronomer, Nicolas‐Louis de Lacaille (1713–62). The catalogue was published in 1763, but Johann Bode retained it in 1801 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 202–3).

Charlesʼs Oak was also treated as an existing constellation by Green in 1824: “Rober Caroli, or Charlesʼs Oak, is to the east of Argo Navis, and contains one star of the first magnitude. Dr. [Edmond] Halley introduced this asterism on the maps in 1676, when he was in the Island of St. Helena. He named it in honour of the oak whose branches concealed Charles II after the battle of Worcester” (Astronomical Recreations, 103). This battle represented the decisive defeat of Royalist forces in the English Civil War, during which the son of the executed king, Charles I, saved his life by hiding in an oak tree. After Charles II was restored to the throne, the purpose of his astronomer, Halley, in traveling to St. Helena was, like Lacailleʼs mission, to survey the southern sky, and he published his star catalogue, including the new honorific constellation, in 1679 (Ridpath, 202).

“Iʼll call it junoʼs cup“ (MS III)—Crater (the Cup) is a southern constellation, clustered togethet with Corvus (the Crow) and Hydra (the Water Snake), which are north of Centaurus. Crater is included among the forty‐eight listed by Ptolemy.

While Ruskin may “call it junoʼs cup”, the best‐known myth assigns the cup to Apollo, in a story involving Corvus and Hydra (Ridpath, Star Tales, 82–83). Green cites writers who associate the cup variously with Bacchus, Noah, and the Platonists (Astronomical Recreations, 101).

“Hercules appeareth high“ (MS III)—The constellation Hercules or Heracles indeed appears higher in the sky than the previous three constellations Ruskin has listed, which are southern and below the celestial equator. Hercules stands on the head of Draco (the Dragon) and between Lyra (the Lyre) and Corona Borealis (Northern Crown). The constellation was listed by Ptolemy among his forty‐eight.

Ridpath remarks that this ancient constellation was known to the poet Aratus only as the kneeling one, and that he was identified belatedly with Heracles by Eratosthenes (Star Tales, 101). Green supplies an ethical interpretation of the hero “celebrated in antiquity for his heroic valour and corporal strength. He is represented in a kneeling posture, holding in his right hand a club, and in his left the Hesperidian branch, with the three‐headed Cerberus; the skin of a lion covers his head and shoulders. This lion he killed in the forests in the neighbourhood of NemÆa, and the celebrated NemÆan games were instituted to commemorate that event. [The astronomer] Hevelius first placed in the hand of this hero the serpent with three heads, or Cerberus. The Hesperidian branch, bearing the golden apples, is probably of a more ancient date. . . . Hercules, among many other achievements, . . . procured some of these golden apples from the Hesperides, by killing the Dragon [Draco]. . . . It is stated by the mythologists, that he brought upon earth the three‐headed monster Cerberus, which guarded the entrance to Plutoʼs dominions. The victory which he obtained over Cerberus, is thought by some to denote his control over his bad passions; for he is held out by the ancients as a pattern of virtue and piety. His judicious choice of virtue, in preference to pleasure, is admirably described by Xenophon” (Astronomical Recreations, 46–47).

“cerberus in the sky“ (MS III)—Ruskin places Cerberus next, not just by association with Hercules, who slew the monster, but also by its position in the sky. As a constellation, Cerberus was created by the astronomer, Johannes Hevelius, who put the creature in Herculesʼs hand in place of the Herperidian branch. Thereafter, the branch and Cerberus were grasped together by Hercules, up through Bodeʼs depiction in 1801. As Green acknowledged in 1824, "there is a group of small stars, of the fourth and fifth magnitude, in the branch, intertwined with serpents, which Hercules holds in his hand. These serpents are called by some Cerberus (Astronomical Recreations, 46). Cerberus is now obsolete as a constellation.

“The lizard“ (MS III)—Lacerta (the Lizard) is between Cygnus and Andromeda. The constellation was introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, and augmented with a few more stars by an English astronomer, John Flamsteed (1646-1719), in a posthumous publication of 1725 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 111-12).

div.note: Note the serpent and serpent bearer are two different constellations.
Note These constellations though they are next in this poetry are not next in the sky.
